description: First attested since 1300s, from Middle English rablen (“to ramble; rave; speak in a confused manner”), cognate with Middle Dutch rabbelen (“to talk; chatter; trifle”), Low German rabbeln, robbeln (“to chatter; prattle”).

verbs.description: rabble (third-person singular simple present rabbles, present participle rabbling, simple past and past participle rabbled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To speak in a confused manner; talk incoherently; utter nonsense
(transitive) To speak confusedly or incoherently; gabble or chatter out

description: From Middle English rabel, probably from the verb (see above).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A bewildered or meaningless string of words.
(obsolete) A pack of animals; or any confused collection of things.
A mob; a disorderly crowd. [from late 14th c.]
(derogatory) The mass of common people; the lowest class of populace. [from 1550s]
examples: Synonyms: plebs, riffraff; see also Thesaurus:commonalty

description: Old French roable (modern French râble), from Latin rutabulum (“a poker”).

entries.meaning: An iron bar used in puddling.

verbs.description: rabble (third-person singular simple present rabbles, present participle rabbling, simple past and past participle rabbled)
